concept.title: Types of Logic
concept.shortdesc: An overview and examples of different types of logic, including propositional logic, predicate logic, and modal logic.

section.title: Introduction
section.p:
Logic is central to the process of reasoning. We use logic to help us form, evaluate, and draw conclusions about arguments. There are several types of logic, each with its own purposes and applications. I will briefly cover three types of logic:
Propositional Logic
Predicate Logic
Modal Logic

section.title: Propositional Logic
section.p: Propositonal logic (aka Sentential Logic) *deals with* propositions and the relationship between propositions. In propsitional logic, we translate natural lause operators and sentence symbols to translate

section.title: Predicate Logic
section.p: Predicate logic (aka Predicate Calculus) expands on propositional logic by *dealing with* predicates and quantifiers.

conbody.example:
Examples
The dog is red and brown.
R = is red, B = is brown, d = the dog Rd ∧ Bd
Read: "The dog is red, and the dog is brown."
The dog is red and brown.
R = is red, B = is brown, D = is a dog ∃x (Dx ∧ (Rx ∧ Bx))
Read: "There exists some x, such that x is a dog, and x is red, and x is brown."
All dogs are mammals.
M = is a mammal, D = is a dog ∀x (Dx ⊃ Mx)
Read: "For all things that exist, if x is a dog, then x is a mammal or x is an animal." You may wonder where how we can get away with adding the conditional words "if" and "then." The reason for the conditional will be explained later.

Examples
If Helga might bring her dog, then Hans will definitly stay home.
D = Helga might bring her dog, S = Hans will definitely stay home ∀x (◇ Px ⊃ □ (Ph ⊃ Ch))
Read: "If it is possible that Helga will bring her dog, that Hans will necessarily stay home."
Of all the people who might be at the party, Herman would definitely be the coolest.
D = Helga might bring her dog, S = Hans will definitely stay home ◇D ⊃ □S
Read: "If it is possible that Helga will bring her dog, that Hans will necessarily stay home."
